Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Compatibilization Studies of Bulk and Thin Film Polymer Blends with Copolymer Additives
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL:

Compatibilized polymer blends continue to be important in traditional bulk applications as well as in thin film related applications (e.g., polymer solar cells, fuel cell membranes, and battery technology). A better understanding of how copolymer additives can enhance polymer blends will enable further advances in these technologies. The research to be conducted as part of this Research in Undergraduate Institution (RUI) renewal award will broaden the knowledge of how copolymer structure can influence bulk and thin film polymer blends. The research will be conducted on compatibilized polymer blends divided into two main areas, bulk blends and thin film blends. Both areas of research will investigate the influence of copolymer additive structure. First, the copolymer effect on the bulk polymer blends will be investigated using scattering techniques, solid state NMR, and atomic force microscopy focusing on thermodynamics and interfacial properties. Second, compatibilization of thin film polymer blends will be investigated with atomic force microscopy both as static films as well as at higher temperatures studying the dewetting and phase separation kinetics. The primary polymer system to be studied is a blend of polybutadiene and polystyrene homopolymers with the additives being various diblock, triblock, and tetrablock copolymers of butadiene and styrene. The research will take place in a predominantly undergraduate institution, providing summer research experiences for at least four undergraduate students. Outreach activities are also be included that provide opportunities for underrepresented students through the local Mathematics, Engineering, and Science Achievement (MESA) program.

NON-TECHNICAL:

Some of today's biggest challenges include providing clean energy production through new solar energy and fuel cell technology. The capability of manufacturing high performance materials, which can address needs in these technologies, is very import. Similar advanced materials can impact many other technologies as well, ranging from environmentally friendly roofing materials, mobile devices, coatings, to critical components in automobiles. The research to be conducted as part of this NSF Research in Undergraduate Institutions renewal award will help increase our fundamental knowledge of how to make these kinds of materials with tailored properties and may eventually lead to an increased ability to manufacture new plastics with specific properties. Undergraduate students will be the primary participants in this research giving them vital experience and facilitating their movement into post-baccalaureate education as well as in the scientific work force. This award will also be beneficial to the educational efforts of the principal investigator's institution through the broadening of research experiences for undergraduate students during the summer and the academic year. Outreach activities are also included that bring underrepresented high school students from a local Mathematics, Engineering, and Science Achievement (MESA) program to our labs for a polymer materials workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The advancement of new materials is often accomplished by either the creation of new materials or by the manner in which materials are packed together. This goal of this project was to investigate blends of both industry standard polymers, polystyrene (PS) and polybutadiene (PB), and a relatively new class of polymers based on decorated norbornene monomers and how special copolymer additives can affect these blends.  Controlling the structures that are made when polymers are blended (morphology) can have a significant impact on materials that are important for addressing new technologies such as batteries, solar cells, and more traditional ones such as in the automotive industry. Ultimately, the understanding of how these materials can be blended will lead to improved products.

The major outcomes of this research are organized into two groups based on the polymer systems studied. The first area of work is focused on a model polymer blend system of PS and PB. Solid state NMR (13C CP-MAS) was used to study the localization of various additives (copolymers) in different regions of blend morphology. Deuterated and non-deuterated materials were used to allow the measurements to focus on the location of additives in the blend. A random copolymer and a diblock copolymer were studied. The diblock copolymer mediated the interface between the PS and PB rich regions best and is an outcome that is consistent previous work. Similar blend systems were studied as thin films using atomic force microscopy (AFM). Additional research was pursued to synthesize a special kind of block copolymer with four arms instead of two using a unique small molecule. A synthetic pathway was established to make this small linker molecule and almost completed but will need to be modified to finish this work. The second part of the research was the development of a unique class of polymers, which might be used for polymer blends with tailored properties. We utilized a Grubbs catalyst to make a series of polymers with a bulky backbone and a variety of side chains. This work entailed the synthesis of monomers that were not commercially available. These polymers were synthesized with precision both in their length and in the distribution of their lengths for a wide variety of side chains.  These monomers also allowed the synthesis of diblock copolymers with equally well controlled properties. A diblock copolymer with equal volumes of each monomer was studied also using AFM and X-Ray scattering. This material was able to demonstrate good microphase phase separation with a nanomophology of roughly forty nanometers. This system appears to hold much promise for future study.

Educating a broad and diverse work force is very important for our society and encouraging a diverse range of students to become trained in science will benefit STEM and health-care fields. One of the highlights of the broader impact of this award is the training that undergraduate student receive. Undergraduate students have conducted all of this research. This project has provided excellent research experiences for eight undergraduate students during the span of the award with a majority of the students being women. Of these eight students, five are now either in graduate school or applying for graduate school in chemistry and two are pursuing medical school. Sadly, one of the research students passed away on a personal hiking trip during the summer program. These research experiences also contributed to the larger culture of undergraduate research at our institution both during the summer program and during the academic year. It has also reached into the classroom as well through discussions and demonstrations. Five of the student researchers presented their results at the spring 2011 and 2012 American Chemical Society national meetings.
